items.content_html:
Summary

From changelog: https://webkit.org/blog/13966/webkit-features-in-safari-16-4/

Safari 16.4 adds support for CSS Properties and Values API with support for the @Property at-rule. It greatly extends the capabilities of CSS variables by allowing developers to specify the syntax of the variable, the inheritance behavior, and the variable initial value â€” similar to how browser engines define CSS properties.
items.title: Safari added support for @property in version 16.4

Summary

Safari shipped the shadowrootmode attribute for Declarative Shadow DOM in version 16.4. Release notes here: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-16_4-release-notes

A prior blog post that shows the Technology Preview version it first shipped in: https://webkit.org/blog/13851/declarative-shadow-dom/
items.title: Safari shipped shadowrootmode in 16.4

items.content_html:
Summary

This adds all of the API for global attributes and properties with relation to the Popover API. I worked on this mostly to get the ball rolling. Chrome 114 is slated to ship this but it has not definitely shipped to a browser.

Test results and supporting details

These are available in the specification: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-popover-attribute

Related issues

mdn/content#25125

items.content_html:
Summary

The initial implementation of webextensions.api.action was a clone of webextensions.api.browser_action including support for sub-features. However, the initial BCD didn't include the sub-feature details, this change add those details.

Related issues

Fixes #19103
items.title: Add missing subfeatures to webextensions.api.action

items.content_html:
This PR removes the displayName member of the Function JavaScript builtin from BCD. Per the data guidelines, this feature can be considered irrelevant and may be removed from BCD accordingly. Even if the current data suggests that the feature is supported, lack of support has been confirmed by the mdn-bcd-collector project (v8.2.0).

Tests Used: https://mdn-bcd-collector.gooborg.com/tests/javascript/builtins/Function/displayName
items.title: Remove javascript.builtins.Function.displayName from BCD

items.content_html: This PR re-adds a note regarding Atomics being gated behind COOP and COEP in Safari in older versions. This reverts its removal in #16047.
items.title: Mention COOP/COEP requirement for Atomics for Safari

items.content_html:
Summary

There are several features of the WebAuthn API that are not covered on MDN, so I've started a project to update these docs, filling in gaps and improving the available information. I've also checked through the available BCD to see what is missing.

This PR does the following:

  • Adds data for the publickey-credentials-create Permissions-Policy directive
    • For this data, I'm just copying the publickey-credentials-get data, assuming they would both be implemented at the same time. I don't see why they'd be implemented at different times â€” they are both needed together to be useful.
  • Adds data for the publicKey options of CredentialsContainer.create() and CredentialsContainer.get() â€” I thought it important to call these out separately, as well as individual sub-items that were implemented later than the initial implementation. I don't want to create data points for the entire hierarchy of sub-properties, as it would be time-consuming and not very useful (we won't have separate pages for those properties, as they are members of a dictionary, not a class.)
    • for the basic publicKey data, I'm just copying the data for the PublicKeyCredential interface, as one returned the other, and I don't see that they'd be implemented separately.
    • for credProps, residentKey, and requireResidentKey, see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5701094648840192
    • for largeBlob, see https://chromestatus.com/feature/5657899357437952

Test results and supporting details

Related issues
items.title: Add WebAuthn latest feature data and make it more descriptive

items.content_html:
Summary

Added partial support for Fetch Metadata request headers in Safari 16.4+:

  • Sec-Fetch-Dest
  • Sec-Fetch-Mode
  • Sec-Fetch-Site

Test results and supporting details

Note: I have only tested on a personal iPad running Safari 16.4

The release notes are limited and mentions of the feature are scattered throughout the following locations:

Main references
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=204744
WebKit/WebKit#6211

Other mentions
WebKit/WebKit#4186
WebKit/WebKit#11027
WebKit/WebKit#6296
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=237550

Related issues

None
items.title: Partial Safari support for Fetch metadata request headers

items.content_html:
Summary

Starting from version 113 Firefox will no longer support cache clearing via the clearSiteData header. It was already disabled by default since 94.

Test results and supporting details

Bugzilla bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1821651
Phabricator: https://phabricator.services.mozilla.com/D173282

Related issues
items.title: WIP: Fx support for cache clearing via clearSiteData header runs out in fx113

Related issues
items.title: Fixes #18934

items.content_html:
FF110 implements the "focus fixup rule" on elements in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1810077.

This was basically a spec clarification to state what happened to the focus and blur/focus events if focus was lost on an element because:

  • A style like hidden was applied to the element, which cannot accept focus.
  • The element was removed.

The spec changes says that the first case means blur event should fire, and focus should move to the body/viewport. For removal of element from document the focus should move to the body but blur should not fire.
Prior to FF110 FF would not release focus even if the style was set to hidden, so the event was not fired. This makes the change so that it is. This matches chromium.
There are some tests:

  • http://wpt.live/css/selectors/focus-display-none-001.html
  • http://wpt.live/inert/dynamic-inert-on-focused-element.html

Anyway, the developers are not sure if BCD entry is warranted. Neither am I, but I'd hate to lose what information we have now, so I have added a note to record this.

Other docs work can be tracked in mdn/content#25496
items.title: FF110 focus fixup rule on Elements
